Source code for havoc.autoval.lib.host.inband

from __future__ import absolute_import
from __future__ import division
from __future__ import print_function
from __future__ import unicode_literals
import re
from havoc.autotest_testfiles.validation_utils.lib.autoval import AutovalUtils
from havoc.autotest_testfiles.validation_utils.lib.autoval_exceptions import TestError
import time

PCR_COMMANDS = [
    'cat /sys/class/tpm/tpm0/device/pcrs',
    'cat /sys/class/misc/tpm0/device/pcrs'
]



[docs]class Inband(object):


[docs]    def __init__(self, host):
        self.host = host
        self.localhost = host.localhost
        self.bmc = host.product_obj.bmc(self.host, self.host, oob_addr=None)


    def __getattr__(self, name):
        return getattr(self.bmc, name)


[docs]    def get_ipmi_host(self):
        return self.host



[docs]    def shutdown(self):
        '''
        This command will just shutdown the system using 'init 0' command and
        the system is not brought back up
        This is mainly used in the time of bios flashing to do a graceful
        shutdown to avoid Tboot issue
        This supports only OpenBMC systems currently
        '''
        power_cmd = "shutdown -h now"
        try:
            self.host.run(power_cmd)
        except Exception:
            expected_time = time.time() + 100
            shutdown_status = False
            while time.time() < expected_time:
                try:
                    # this is expected to fail as system goes down and unable to
                    # connect else wait for 10 secs for the system to go down
                    self.host.run("hostname")
                    time.sleep(10)
                except Exception:
                    # unable to run the command as system is down
                    shutdown_status = True
                    break

            if not shutdown_status:
                raise TestError("The system din't shutdown in expected time")



[docs]    def reboot(self, shutdown_cmd=False, timeout=1200):
        # Get last reboot time from system and use it to validate the reconnect
        current_reboot = self.host.get_last_reboot()

        if shutdown_cmd:
            power_cmd = 'shutdown -r +0'
        else:
            power_cmd = '/sbin/reboot'

        try:
            self.host.run(power_cmd)
        except Exception as e:
            if re.search('/sbin/reboot.* failed', str(e)):
                AutovalUtils.log_info("Server reboot started")
            else:
                raise

        # Reconnect the system
        self.host.system_health_check(current_reboot, timeout)



[docs]    def get_ip(self, ip_type="inet", interface="eth0"):
        # ip_type can be inet or inet6

        out = self.host.run("ip addr show %s" % (interface))

        if ip_type == "inet":
            m = re.search(r"%s (\S+)\/.*" % (ip_type), out)
            if m:
                ip = m.group(1)
                AutovalUtils.log_info("IP is: %s" % (ip))
                return ip
            else:
                raise TestError("Did not find IP type %s in %s" %
                                   (ip_type, out))
        elif ip_type == "inet6":
            m = re.search(r"inet6 (\S+)\/.*scope global", out)
            if m:
                ip = m.group(1)
                AutovalUtils.log_info("IP is: %s" % (ip))
                return ip
            else:
                raise TestError("Did not find IP type %s in %s"
                                    % (ip_type, out))
        else:
            raise TestError("Unknown IP type %s" % (ip_type))



[docs]    def check_tpm(self, host):
        cmd = "ls /sys/class/tpm/"
        out = self.host.run(cmd)
        if "tpm0" in out:
            return True
        else:
            try:
                # Some systems have different location
                cmd = "ls /sys/class/misc/tpm/"
                out = self.host.run(cmd)
                if "tpm0" in out:
                    return True
            except Exception:
                return False



[docs]    def get_tpm_version(self, host):
        cmd = "dmesg | grep -i TPM"
        out = self.host.run(cmd, ignore_status=True)
        if out:
            ver = re.search(r"[1-2].[0-9]+\s+TPM", out)
            AutovalUtils.validate_condition(ver, "check for TPM version",
                log_on_pass=False)
            version = ver.group(0).split()[0]
            return version
        if self.check_tpm(host):
            raise TestError("Unable to detect TPM version")
        else:
            raise TestError("TPM is not detected")



[docs]    def get_tpm_sha(self, host):
        # Return supported TPM_Bank/Algorithm
        version = self.get_tpm_version(host)
        SHA = ["not available for TPM 1.2"]
        if version >= "2.0":
            cmd = "/sbin/tpm2_listpcrs -s"
            out = self.host.run(cmd)
            SHA = re.findall(r"0x000\S", out)
            AutovalUtils.validate_greater(len(SHA), 0, "Verify SHA value",
                log_on_pass=False)
        return SHA



[docs]    def get_pcr0(self, host):
        pcrs = self.get_pcrs(host)
        return pcrs[0]



[docs]    def get_pcrs(self, host, SHA="0x0004"):
        # PCR location and command to get PCR differs depending on
        # kernel version determine the location and fetch the PCR value
        version = self.get_tpm_version(host)
        if version >= "2.0":
            cmd = "/sbin/tpm2_listpcrs -g %s" % SHA
            out = self.host.run(cmd)
        else:
            out = ""
            for cmd in PCR_COMMANDS:
                try:
                    out = self.host.run(cmd)
                    break
                except Exception:
                    pass

        pattern = re.compile(r'^PCR[-_]\d+:\s+(.+)$', re.MULTILINE)
        pcrs = []
        for line in out.split('\n'):
            match = re.search(pattern, line)
            if match:
                pcrs.append(match.group(1))

        if not pcrs:
            raise TestError("Couldn't extract PCR value")
        else:
            return pcrs



[docs]    def get_kernel_version(self, short=False):
        cmd = "uname -r"
        try:
            kernel_ver = self.host.run(cmd)
        except Exception:
            raise TestError("CMD: %s failed" % (cmd))
        if short:
            pattern = r"\d+.\d+.\d+-\d+_fbk\d+"
            kernel_ver = re.search(pattern, kernel_ver).group(0)

        return kernel_ver



[docs]    def kernel_installer(self, kernel_version, reinstall):
        """ When kernel_version is set to "latest" it gets updated to the latest
        available version. If reinstall is true, kernel gets reinstalled. """

        bios_vendor = self.host.bios.get_bios_vendor()
        try:
            if kernel_version != 'latest':
                new_ver = self.validate_kernel_version(kernel_version)
                cur_ver_full = self.get_kernel_version()
                cur_ver = extract_kernel_version(cur_ver_full)

                if (cur_ver != new_ver) or reinstall:
                    AutovalUtils.log_info("Curr Ver:%s - Starting Kernel"
                            " update" % (cur_ver_full))
                else:
                    AutovalUtils.log_info("Curr Ver:%s, New Ver:%s, No"
                            " update needed" % (cur_ver_full, kernel_version))
                    return True

                cmd = ("/usr/local/bin/kernel-installer -k %s --devel --headers -q"
                        % (new_ver))

                self.host.run(cmd)
                if bios_vendor != "coreboot":
                    # @@@ TODO: Chef is currently broken with coreboot.
                    # Remove this when it's fixed
                    self.host.run("chefctl -i")
                self.reboot(shutdown_cmd=True)

                updated_version_full = self.get_kernel_version()
                AutovalUtils.log_info("After update, current version reported is %s" %
                                      (updated_version_full))
                updated_version = extract_kernel_version(updated_version_full)

                if updated_version == new_ver:
                    AutovalUtils.log_info(
                        "Update to %s completed" % (kernel_version))
                else:
                    raise TestError(
                        "Kernel update to {} failed {}".format(
                            new_ver, updated_version))
                return True
            else:
                AutovalUtils.log_info("Starting kernel upgrade to latest version.")
                self.host.run("kernel-installer --imp -q")
                if bios_vendor != "coreboot":
                    # @@@ TODO: Chef is currently broken with coreboot.
                    # Remove this when it's fixed
                    self.host.run("chefctl -i")
                self.reboot(shutdown_cmd=True)
                updated_version_full = self.get_kernel_version()
                AutovalUtils.log_info(
                    "After update, current version reported is {}".format(
                        updated_version_full))

        except Exception as e:
            AutovalUtils.log_info(
                "Kernel update to {} failed: {}".format(kernel_version, e))
            raise TestError(str(e))



[docs]    def validate_kernel_version(self, check_version):
        version = extract_kernel_version(check_version)

        cmd = "/usr/local/bin/kernel-installer -l"
        out = self.host.run(cmd)
        valid_kernel = False
        if out:
            for line in out.split("\n"):
                m = re.match(version, line)
                if m:
                    valid_kernel = True
        if not valid_kernel:
            raise TestError("Kernel %s not available" % version)
        else:
            return version


    """
    ## Function to check if a kernel module is enabled or disabled
    # @param - List of kernel modules to check
    # @return - dict with each module,Enabled or disabled.
    """


[docs]    def check_kernel_module(self, kernel_parms):
        config_status = {}
        ver = self.host.run("uname -r")
        conf_file = "/boot/config-%s" % (ver)
        try:
            k_config = self.host.run("cat %s" % conf_file)
        except Exception:
            conf_file = "/usr/src/kernels/*/.config"
            k_config = self.host.run("cat %s" % conf_file)
        for params in kernel_parms:
            status = "disabled"
            if "%s=y" % params in k_config:
                status = "enabled"
            config_status[params] = status
        return config_status




[docs]def extract_kernel_version(full_version):
    m = re.search(r"(\d+.\d+.\d+-\d+_fbk\d+)", full_version)
    if m:
        return m.group(1)
    else:
        raise TestError("Invalid Kernel version %s" % full_version)
